attributes.title: Internet Gaming Behavior and Parents’ Feedback Styles
attributes.description: This project aims to figure out whether parents' feedback will influence their children's Internet gaming behavior. The Internet Gaming Disorder Scale will be tested to find out the effect of autonomous or controlling style of feedback. And other indicators such as Treatment Self-Regulation Scale and concealment as well as reactance will also be measured to figure out the underlying mechanism.

q1.value: Impact of Autonomous Versus Controlling Styles of Parents' Feedbacks on Maladaptive Internet Gaming Behavior

q3.value: Previous studies have shown that parental styles affect children's technology uses. However, the effect of how different parents' feedback styles on real-life technology use, i.e., maladaptive Internet gaming behavior, remains unknown. Hence, the current study will mainly measure how parents' feedback styles (autonomous, controlling, and neutral styles) effect on Internet gaming behavior. Besides, self-regulation, perceived trustworthiness, and reactance are also measured to detect whether they mediate the effect of parents' feedback styles on the maladaptive Internet gaming behavior.

q4.value:
(1)If parents' feedback style affect Internet gaming behavior, then autonomous feedback style decreases their children’s Internet gaming addiction. And controlling feedback style increases their children’s  Internet gaming addiction. 
(2) Autonomous feedback style increases children’s self-regulation. Controlling feedback style decreases their children’s  self-regulation.
(3)Self-regulation mediates the effect of parents' feedback styles on Internet gaming addiction. 
(4)The autonomous feedback style decreases children’s reactance. The controlling feedback style increases children’s reactance. 
(5)Reactance mediates the effect of parents' feedback styles on Internet gaming addiction. 
(6)The autonomous feedback style increases children’s perceived trustworthiness. The controlling feedback style decreases children’s perceived trustworthiness.
(7)Perceived trustworthiness mediates the effect of parents' feedback styles on Internet gaming addiction.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.
Personnel who interact directly with the study subjects (either human or non-human subjects) will not be aware of the assigned treatments. (Commonly known as “double blind”)

question.value: This study is a between-subject design with 1 independent variable(parents' feedback styles) of 3 levels (neutral, autonomous and controlling). The outcome variables are Internet gaming addiction, self-regulation, reactance, perceived trustworthiness. The whole study will be conducted in Chinese, which will be adapted to the Chinese cultural context and avoid misunderstanding of the questions. The study uses the projective approach and is delivered as a questionnaire. The online questionnaire system will randomly assign the participant to different conditions in the questionnaire. Participants need to read a scenario about how parents give feedback on their children's maladaptive Internet gaming behavior. Then, participants need to imagine that they are the character(the children) in the scenario and answer some questions based on the scenario they are assigned. The questions are assessing participants' Internet gaming addiction, self-regulation, reactance, and perceived trustworthiness.

q9.value: I will use block randomization in the study to ensure that each participant will have an equal chance to be assigned to different conditions of the manipulation. When the participant is assigned to a specific condition, they need to fill in the same question based on their assigned condition. The randomization will be conducted by Qualtrics.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: 158 Chinese undergraduates will be recruited as participants through online posting, mainly by the common social media in Chinese, i.e. Wechat and Whatsapp. Participants can access the questionnaire of this study from online advertisements. After fulfilling the consent form, the participants need to complete the whole questionnaire. When they complete the questionnaire, they will be paid 20 Hong Kong dollar cash to compensate for their effort in the study.

q13.value: The target sample size of this study is 158 participants. We will attempt to recruit nearly 200 participants to increase the power of the study. Also, considering some participants may not meet the requirements of the study, we want to include around 200 participants in the study.

q14.value: We used the software program G*Power to conduct a power analysis. Our goal is to obtain .80 power to detect a medium effect size of .25 at the standard .05 alpha error probability.

q15.value: This study is a student's Honour Project, and due to the time limit, we will collect as many participants as possible within two weeks. Data collection will be terminated when the number of participants reaches 158. Or the study will end within one month.

question.value: We manipulated the parents' feedback style on Internet gaming behavior. The three levels of this categorical variable are: autonomous, controlling, and neutral styles.

The outcome variables are Internet gaming addiction, self-regulation, reactance, and perceived trustworthiness. Internet gaming addiction will be measured by the means of Internet Gaming Disorder Scale, asking the participants how the following statement describes their status. For example, they need to choose from a scale of 1-5, 1 being " extremely disagree", 5 being "extremely agree" for the statement " I become less interested in the previous entertainment".And I will measure self-regulation by Treatment Self-Regulation Scale, by selecting the most suitable options of the given statement " I think playing/not playing online game is interesting". The reactance and perceived trustworthiness are measured in the same way as self-regulation.

I will use a multiple regression method to analyze the relationship between the predictor (parents' feedback style) and the outcome variable (Internet gaming addiction). At the same time, self-regulation, perceived trustworthiness, and reactance will be tested whether they are mediators of parents' feedback styles on maladaptive online gaming behavior.

q21.value: I will use the standard p< .05 criteria for determining the regression and the mediator model.

q22.value: I will verify whether the participants meet my selection requirements. For example, if the participants do not agree to participate in the study, or they are not the current undergraduate students, or they are not from China, their data will be excluded. Besides, the questionnaire includes three attention checks to ensure they complete the questionnaire carefully. Hence,  if they fail to respond correctly twice for the attention checks, their data will be excluded. Also, if the participants do not complete the whole questionnaire, their data will not count.

q24.value: I expect that the similarity from the given scenario and the participants'  personal experience, the relationship between the participants and their parents, and the imagination extent of the scenario may influence the participants' choice. So, I will look for the relationship between these factors and Internet gaming addiction.

q1.value: Cortical and subcortical structural alterations in specific phobia: Results from the ENIGMA Specific Phobia Working Group

q2.value: Kevin Hilbert, Nynke Groenewold, Janna Marie Bas-Hoogendam, Neda Jahanshad, Paul Thompson, ENIGMA Anxiety Specific Phobia working group, Dan Stein, Nic van der Wee, Ulrike Lueken

q3.value:
The “Enhancing Neuro Imaging Genetics through Meta Analysis” (ENIGMA) consortium aims to conduct large-scale analyses of genetic or neuroimaging data in order to facilitate the understanding of healthy or disordered brain structure and function. Within the network, individual working groups focus on specific disorders, syndromes or methods. Often, a working group will aim to recruit as many originals projects, researchers and datasets relevant to it’s topic, provide a standardized ENIGMA analysis pipeline for (re-)analysis of the original data, and integrate the results of the original groups into one, final analysis. Thompson et al. (preprint) provides an extensive overview on ENIGMA. 

Within this network and the ENIGMA-Anxiety working group, the ENIGMA-Specific Phobia (SP) project targets the neuroanatomy of SP in children and adults. Up to now, data from 32 individual research projects from around the globe have been contributed, with a total n = 1.325 for SP subjects and n = 3.212 for healthy controls. The number of SP subjects is expected to rise to n > 1.500 once all sites contributed their data. All contributors provide structural magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) images from subjects with SP, overwhelmingly with additional healthy comparison subjects. 

The ENIGMA-Specific Phobia project will compare subcortical volumes, cortical thickness and cortical surface area between SP and healthy comparison subjects. In addition, we will examine a potential influence of phobia subtype (such as animal phobia, blood-injection-injury phobia) on brain morphometry and associations with symptom severity and depressive symptomatology. Previous studies investigating alterations in structural brain anatomy of SP are scarce. So far, these studies reported differences in a diverse set of brain regions, including the amygdala, insula, and parts of the anterior cingulate (Fisler et al., 2014; Fisler et al., 2013; Hilbert, Evens, Maslowski, Wittchen, & Lueken, 2015; Linares et al., 2014; Rauch et al., 2004; Schienle, Scharmuller, Leutgeb, Schafer, & Stark, 2013; Wabnegger, Scharmüller, & Schienle, 2014). However, the direction of these differences was mixed, the methods used for investigation differed considerably and findings were overall rarely replicated. Additionally, the samples sizes were limited with the average phobia group including n = 27 subjects in these investigations. 

Given the inconsistency in these reports, we referred on our own structural and functional MRI studies in specific phobia (Hilbert, Evens, Maslowski, Wittchen, & Lueken, 2014; Hilbert et al., 2015; Lueken et al., 2014; Lueken et al., 2011), on functional results in specific phobia (Linares et al., 2012) and on fundamental findings of how (clinical) anxiety is underpinned in the brain (Sylvester et al., 2012) in order to derive the hypotheses below.

q4.value:
1) Main effect of phobia
Research question I: Is SP regardless of its subtype characterized by altered cortical thickness and surface area in cortical brain regions (particular focus on insula, dorsal anterior cingulate) and in changes in subcortical volumes (amygdala, thalamus)?
Hypothesis I (non-directional): Compared to healthy control (HC) subjects, subjects with SP will show altered cortical thickness and surface area in the dorsal anterior cingulate cortex and the insula, and altered subcortical volumes in the amygdala and thalamus regardless of specific phobia subtype.

2) Phobia subtype:
Research question II: Are there differences between the animal subtype and the BII subtype (including dental phobia) regarding these areas?
Hypothesis II (non-directional): In addition to the alterations outlined in H1, animal phobia subjects will show altered amygdala and thalamus volumes when compared to HC or BII phobia subjects, while BII phobia subjects will show altered cortical thickness and surface area in OFC areas when compared to HC or animal phobia subjects.

3) Symptom Severity: 
Research question III: Is there an association between altered cortical thickness, surface area and subcortical volumes and severity of phobic symptoms?
Hypothesis III (non-directional): We expect a linear association of cortical thickness and surface area and subcortical volumes in the above mentioned areas as a function of symptom severity within the specific phobia group (and specific phobia subtype groups, respectively).

4) Depressive Symptom Severity:
Research question IV: Is there an association between altered cortical thickness, surface area and subcortical volumes and depressive symptomatology?
Hypothesis IV (non-directional): We expect a linear association of cortical thickness and surface area in the insula, dorsal anterior cingulate cortex and volume of the amygdala as a function of increasing severity of depression within the specific phobia group.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
This is a mega-analysis, where individual subject data from many sites and studies, mostly published, are analyzed together. It is in a way a special meta-analysis where the original studies contribute their individual subject data instead of their summary statistics. 

Research question I: Between-subjects design (specific phobia subjects vs healthy subjects)
Research question II: Between-subjects design (animal phobia subjects vs bii phobia subjects)
Research question III: correlational design (linear association with phobic symptom severity)
Research question IV: correlational design (linear association with depressive symptom severity)

q10.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

q11.value:
This project depends on datasets from individual sites, which often have already been examined and published. If publications are present, these mostly focused on functional correlates of specific phobia and included the structural scans only for preprocessing and anatomical localization. In some cases, the publication was not targeted on the neural correlates of specific phobia specifically. Two of the contributing projects were conducted by PIs of the current study (Dresden Specific Phobia Subtypes study; structural results published in Hilbert et al., 2015; Lueken, Hilbert, Wittchen, Reif, & Hahn, 2015; and SFBTRR-58 Project C09 (SpiderVR); structural results so far unpublished). 
	Regarding data coming from projects without our own involvement, we have so far collected the data, checked for data integrity (e.g. missing data, match of scans to sociodemographics etc.) and, in cases where the individual projects sent us raw T1 scans, preprocessed the data using Freesurfer (FS) according to the ENIGMA protocols. Data has not yet been examined regarding the hypotheses, and some data has not yet been received.

question.value:
There were two potential pathways by which individual projects were able to contribute their data. 1) Individual projects processed their data on site according to the FS-based ENIGMA-protocols and instructions that we provided. Then, they provided us with the resulting subject-level data, i.e. subcortical volumes, cortical thickness and surface area per region, as well as the set of demographic and clinical variables. 2) Individual projects sent us the raw imaging data from the subjects and we ran the ENIGMA-protocols ourselves, resulting again in subject-level data, i.e. subcortical volumes, cortical thickness and surface area per region. Each project decided for one of these pathways individually, often considering available time and resources on site as well as relevant data protection regulations or requirements for data sharing.

Specific phobia subjects inclusion criteria:
-	current or past specific phobia (determined by clinical interview or questionnaire cut-off)
-	minimum ten specific phobia subjects initially available per scanner (pre-quality control)

Specific phobia subjects exclusion criteria:
-	current or history of bipolar disorder
-	current or history of psychosis/schizophrenia
-	exclusion criteria of the original studies and projects which contributed the data

Healthy comparison subjects inclusion criteria:
-	free of any psychiatric disorder

q13.value: Collection of data from contributing projects is still ongoing. Based on already submitted data and data agreed but not yet submitted, we expect a final sample size of n > 1.500 specific phobia subjects and n > 3500 healthy comparison subjects. We will stop collecting further data from projects by March 7th 2020. We expect the number of subjects to be included in the analyses to be around 10% lower due to data quality.

q14.value: We aimed to include as many subjects as possible. In a first step, we searched the literature for structural but also functional MRI studies on specific phobia. The rationale here was that many specific phobia research groups that published analyses on functional correlates also acquired corresponding structural data (e.g. for coregistration). Moreover, we used the ENIGMA-Anxiety working group database, where researchers already participating in other ENIGMA projects stored information about available data for other disorders, to identify additional sources for specific phobia data. Finally, we contacted researchers with a history of research on the neurobiology of anxiety that we assumed might provide additional data. The sample size results from the total contributions of all participating sites.

question.value: none

Research question I: 
Predictor variable: group membership (specific phobia, HC)
Outcome variables: cortical thickness and surface area with particular focus on the insula, dorsal anterior cingulate bilaterally; subcortical volumes with a focus on amygdala and thalamus bilaterally
Covariates: sex, age, education level, ICV, site/scanner

Research question II: 
Predictor variable: group membership (specific phobia animal subtype, specific phobia BII subtype including dental phobia)
Outcome variables: cortical thickness and surface area with particular focus on the insula, dorsal anterior cingulate and orbitofrontal cortex bilaterally; subcortical volumes with a focus on amygdala and thalamus bilaterally
Covariates: sex, age, education level, ICV, site/scanner

Research question III: 
Predictor variable: main severity questionnaire used for phobic stimulus, if available: STAI, ASI or HAM-A as overarching measures of anxiety
Outcome variables: cortical thickness and surface area with particular focus on the insula, dorsal anterior cingulate and orbitofrontal cortex bilaterally; subcortical volumes with a focus on amygdala and thalamus bilaterally
Covariates: sex, age, education level, ICV, site/scanner

Research question IV: 
Predictor variable: main severity questionnaire used for depressive symptoms, if available: BDI,
HAM-D or others
Outcome variables: cortical thickness and surface area with particular focus on the insula, dorsal anterior cingulate bilaterally; subcortical volumes with a focus on amygdala bilaterally 
Covariates: sex, age, education level, ICV, site/scanner

If the specific phobia severity and depression severity measures from research questions III and IV are heterogeneous across sites, we will classify subjects into ten centiles according to their questionnaires score within their specific study. The centiles will then be carried forward into ordinal regressions with centiles as predictor variable (specific phobia subjects only).

Analysis outline per research question:
1) Predictor variable: group membership (specific phobia, HC)
Outcome variables: cortical thickness and surface area with particular focus on the insula, dorsal anterior cingulate bilaterally; subcortical volumes with a focus on amygdala and thalamus bilaterally
Covariates: sex, age, ICV, site/scanner
Analysis: The analysis procedure will include a ROI-based approach on the following FS regions: caudal ACC (as approximation for the dorsal ACC), insula, amygdala, thalamus, and an exploratory ‘whole-brain’ approach including all cortical and subcortical FS regions except cerebellum and ventricle regions. In accordance with established ENIGMA methods FS derived individual cortical thickness and surface area and subcortical volumes will be used as input in a linear mixed model including diagnosis (specific phobia, HC) as variable of interest and age, sex, site/scanner and ICV as fixed and scanner as random factor. Additionally, the influence of education level will be also explored. Due to considerations regarding multiple testing, left and right side cortical thickness, surface area and subcortical volumes will be averaged.

2) Predictor variable: group membership (specific phobia animal subtype, specific phobia BII subtype including dental phobia)
Outcome variables: cortical thickness and surface area with particular focus on the insula, dorsal anterior cingulate and orbitofrontal cortex bilaterally; subcortical volumes with a focus on amygdala and thalamus bilaterally
Covariates: sex, age, ICV, site/scanner
Analysis: Similar to the analysis for research question 1, but with diagnosis subtype (animal subtype, BII subtype) as variable of interest.

3) Predictor variable: main severity questionnaire used for phobic stimulus, if available: State-Trait Anxiety Inventory, Anxiety Sensitivity Index, or Hamilton Anxiety Rating Scale as overarching measures of anxiety
Outcome variables: cortical thickness and surface area with particular focus on the insula, dorsal anterior cingulate and orbitofrontal cortex bilaterally; subcortical volumes with a focus on amygdala and thalamus bilaterally
Covariates: sex, age, ICV, site/scanner
Analysis: For this research question, subjects will be classified into ten centiles according to their primary symptom severity questionnaire score within their original study. The reason for this approach is that the original projects used very different severity measures. The centiles will then be carried forward into ordinal regressions with centiles as predictor variable (specific phobia subjects only), once for all subtypes combined and once for each subtype separately. FS derived individual cortical thickness, surface area and subcortical volumes will serve as outcome variables and sex, age, education level, site/scanner and ICV as covariates. If available, we will also perform this analysis with STAI, ASI and HAM-A values.

4) Predictor variable: main severity questionnaire used for depressive symptoms, if available: Beck Depression Inventory-II, Hamilton Depression Rating Scale or others
Outcome variables: cortical thickness and surface area with particular focus on the insula, dorsal anterior cingulate bilaterally; subcortical volumes with a focus on amygdala bilaterally
Covariates: sex, age, ICV, site/scanner
Analysis: Similar to the approach for 3), but with the main severity measure for depression. If available, we will replicate this analysis with BDI-II and HAM-D values.

q21.value: We correct p-values so that the false-discovery rate (FDR)  is limited at 5% according to the approach by Benjamini and Hochberg (1995).

q22.value:
Data from original projects with less than ten specific phobia subjects initially available per scanner (pre-quality control) will be excluded.
	Once data has been submitted, the FS output will be quality controlled using established ENIGMA-Anxiety guidelines for subcortical and cortical areas.

q23.value: Participants missing the necessary predictor variables, outcome variables or covariates for the research question will be excluded.

q24.value:
We may perform exploratory analyses on the influence of medication status, age, education and the impact of formal diagnoses (with diagnostic interview) against questionnaire cut-offs.
Additionally, we may perform exploratory analyses where we replace the statistical models outlined above with supervised machine learning approaches (classification for research questions I and II, regression for research questions III and IV, respectively).

	Regarding data coming from projects without our own involvement, we have so far collected the data, checked for data integrity (e.g. missing data, match of scans to sociodemographics etc.) and, in cases where the individual projects sent us raw T1 scans, preprocessed the data using Freesurfer (FS) according to the ENIGMA protocols. Data has not yet been examined regarding the hypotheses, and some data has not yet been received.
registration_responses.q13: Collection of data from contributing projects is still ongoing. Based on already submitted data and data agreed but not yet submitted, we expect a final sample size of n > 1.500 specific phobia subjects and n > 3500 healthy comparison subjects. We will stop collecting further data from projects by March 7th 2020. We expect the number of subjects to be included in the analyses to be around 10% lower due to data quality.
registration_responses.q14: We aimed to include as many subjects as possible. In a first step, we searched the literature for structural but also functional MRI studies on specific phobia. The rationale here was that many specific phobia research groups that published analyses on functional correlates also acquired corresponding structural data (e.g. for coregistration). Moreover, we used the ENIGMA-Anxiety working group database, where researchers already participating in other ENIGMA projects stored information about available data for other disorders, to identify additional sources for specific phobia data. Finally, we contacted researchers with a history of research on the neurobiology of anxiety that we assumed might provide additional data. The sample size results from the total contributions of all participating sites.
registration_responses.q21: We correct p-values so that the false-discovery rate (FDR)  is limited at 5% according to the approach by Benjamini and Hochberg (1995).
registration_responses.q22:
Data from original projects with less than ten specific phobia subjects initially available per scanner (pre-quality control) will be excluded.
	Once data has been submitted, the FS output will be quality controlled using established ENIGMA-Anxiety guidelines for subcortical and cortical areas.
registration_responses.q23: Participants missing the necessary predictor variables, outcome variables or covariates for the research question will be excluded.
registration_responses.q24:
We may perform exploratory analyses on the influence of medication status, age, education and the impact of formal diagnoses (with diagnostic interview) against questionnaire cut-offs.
Additionally, we may perform exploratory analyses where we replace the statistical models outlined above with supervised machine learning approaches (classification for research questions I and II, regression for research questions III and IV, respectively).
registration_responses.q8.question:
This is a mega-analysis, where individual subject data from many sites and studies, mostly published, are analyzed together. It is in a way a special meta-analysis where the original studies contribute their individual subject data instead of their summary statistics. 

Research question I: Between-subjects design (specific phobia subjects vs healthy subjects)
Research question II: Between-subjects design (animal phobia subjects vs bii phobia subjects)
Research question III: correlational design (linear association with phobic symptom severity)
Research question IV: correlational design (linear association with depressive symptom severity)
registration_responses.q12.question:
There were two potential pathways by which individual projects were able to contribute their data. 1) Individual projects processed their data on site according to the FS-based ENIGMA-protocols and instructions that we provided. Then, they provided us with the resulting subject-level data, i.e. subcortical volumes, cortical thickness and surface area per region, as well as the set of demographic and clinical variables. 2) Individual projects sent us the raw imaging data from the subjects and we ran the ENIGMA-protocols ourselves, resulting again in subject-level data, i.e. subcortical volumes, cortical thickness and surface area per region. Each project decided for one of these pathways individually, often considering available time and resources on site as well as relevant data protection regulations or requirements for data sharing.

Specific phobia subjects inclusion criteria:
-	current or past specific phobia (determined by clinical interview or questionnaire cut-off)
-	minimum ten specific phobia subjects initially available per scanner (pre-quality control)

Specific phobia subjects exclusion criteria:
-	current or history of bipolar disorder
-	current or history of psychosis/schizophrenia
-	exclusion criteria of the original studies and projects which contributed the data

Healthy comparison subjects inclusion criteria:
-	free of any psychiatric disorder
registration_responses.q16.question: none
registration_responses.q17.question:
Research question I: 
Predictor variable: group membership (specific phobia, HC)
Outcome variables: cortical thickness and surface area with particular focus on the insula, dorsal anterior cingulate bilaterally; subcortical volumes with a focus on amygdala and thalamus bilaterally
Covariates: sex, age, education level, ICV, site/scanner

Research question II: 
Predictor variable: group membership (specific phobia animal subtype, specific phobia BII subtype including dental phobia)
Outcome variables: cortical thickness and surface area with particular focus on the insula, dorsal anterior cingulate and orbitofrontal cortex bilaterally; subcortical volumes with a focus on amygdala and thalamus bilaterally
Covariates: sex, age, education level, ICV, site/scanner

Research question III: 
Predictor variable: main severity questionnaire used for phobic stimulus, if available: STAI, ASI or HAM-A as overarching measures of anxiety
Outcome variables: cortical thickness and surface area with particular focus on the insula, dorsal anterior cingulate and orbitofrontal cortex bilaterally; subcortical volumes with a focus on amygdala and thalamus bilaterally
Covariates: sex, age, education level, ICV, site/scanner

Research question IV: 
Predictor variable: main severity questionnaire used for depressive symptoms, if available: BDI,
HAM-D or others
Outcome variables: cortical thickness and surface area with particular focus on the insula, dorsal anterior cingulate bilaterally; subcortical volumes with a focus on amygdala bilaterally 
Covariates: sex, age, education level, ICV, site/scanner
registration_responses.q18.question: If the specific phobia severity and depression severity measures from research questions III and IV are heterogeneous across sites, we will classify subjects into ten centiles according to their questionnaires score within their specific study. The centiles will then be carried forward into ordinal regressions with centiles as predictor variable (specific phobia subjects only).
registration_responses.q19.question:
Analysis outline per research question:
1) Predictor variable: group membership (specific phobia, HC)
Outcome variables: cortical thickness and surface area with particular focus on the insula, dorsal anterior cingulate bilaterally; subcortical volumes with a focus on amygdala and thalamus bilaterally
Covariates: sex, age, ICV, site/scanner
Analysis: The analysis procedure will include a ROI-based approach on the following FS regions: caudal ACC (as approximation for the dorsal ACC), insula, amygdala, thalamus, and an exploratory ‘whole-brain’ approach including all cortical and subcortical FS regions except cerebellum and ventricle regions. In accordance with established ENIGMA methods FS derived individual cortical thickness and surface area and subcortical volumes will be used as input in a linear mixed model including diagnosis (specific phobia, HC) as variable of interest and age, sex, site/scanner and ICV as fixed and scanner as random factor. Additionally, the influence of education level will be also explored. Due to considerations regarding multiple testing, left and right side cortical thickness, surface area and subcortical volumes will be averaged.

2) Predictor variable: group membership (specific phobia animal subtype, specific phobia BII subtype including dental phobia)
Outcome variables: cortical thickness and surface area with particular focus on the insula, dorsal anterior cingulate and orbitofrontal cortex bilaterally; subcortical volumes with a focus on amygdala and thalamus bilaterally
Covariates: sex, age, ICV, site/scanner
Analysis: Similar to the analysis for research question 1, but with diagnosis subtype (animal subtype, BII subtype) as variable of interest.

3) Predictor variable: main severity questionnaire used for phobic stimulus, if available: State-Trait Anxiety Inventory, Anxiety Sensitivity Index, or Hamilton Anxiety Rating Scale as overarching measures of anxiety
Outcome variables: cortical thickness and surface area with particular focus on the insula, dorsal anterior cingulate and orbitofrontal cortex bilaterally; subcortical volumes with a focus on amygdala and thalamus bilaterally
Covariates: sex, age, ICV, site/scanner
Analysis: For this research question, subjects will be classified into ten centiles according to their primary symptom severity questionnaire score within their original study. The reason for this approach is that the original projects used very different severity measures. The centiles will then be carried forward into ordinal regressions with centiles as predictor variable (specific phobia subjects only), once for all subtypes combined and once for each subtype separately. FS derived individual cortical thickness, surface area and subcortical volumes will serve as outcome variables and sex, age, education level, site/scanner and ICV as covariates. If available, we will also perform this analysis with STAI, ASI and HAM-A values.

4) Predictor variable: main severity questionnaire used for depressive symptoms, if available: Beck Depression Inventory-II, Hamilton Depression Rating Scale or others
Outcome variables: cortical thickness and surface area with particular focus on the insula, dorsal anterior cingulate bilaterally; subcortical volumes with a focus on amygdala bilaterally
Covariates: sex, age, ICV, site/scanner
Analysis: Similar to the approach for 3), but with the main severity measure for depression. If available, we will replicate this analysis with BDI-II and HAM-D values.

attributes.title: Amygdala activation to emotional events in a movie fMRI paradigm

data.value: Yes, we already collected the data.

name.value: Amygdala activation to emotional events in a movie fMRI paradigm

other.value: If our current definition of events (two or more consecutive significantly positive timepoints) does not sufficiently capture emotional events in the movie (i.e., if the events end up being shorter than 4s), we will explore using a shorter event definition. We will explore multiple motion thresholds for participant exclusion (e.g., 0.5mm average motion), to assess the robustness of our results. In addition to the amygdala, we will also explore using the nucleus accumbens for reverse correlation analysis.

sample.value: We will collect structural and functional MRI data from 50 typically developing children.

analyses.value:
We will preprocess the functional data using the following steps:

Simultaneous realignment and slice timing correction will be conducted using an algorithm implemented in Nipy (Roche, 2011). Outlier volumes in the functional data will be defined using ART based on composite motion (greater than 1 mm of head displacement between volumes) and global signal intensity (greater than 3 standard deviations from the mean).

The following confounds will be regressed out of the functional data: 6 realignment parameters (3 translations, 3 rotations) and their first-order derivatives, outlier volumes flagged by ART (one nuisance regressor per outlier), composite motion, and linear and quadratic polynomials to detrend the data. Five principal components will also be derived from segmentations of both cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) and white matter (WM), and regressed from the data, in order to help correct for physiological noise like heart rate and respiration (aCompCor; Behzadi, Restom, Liau, & Liu, 2007). 

The functional data will be high-pass filtered (cutoff of 100 s), spatially smoothed with an isotropic 6 mm Gaussian kernel (FWHM), and normalized to the OASIS-30 Atropos template (in MNI152 2 mm space) in a two-step process. First, the median functional image will be coregistered to the reconstructed surfaces using FreeSurfer’s bbregister (Greve & Fischl, 2009); next, the structural image will be registered to the OASIS-30 Atropos MNI152 template using ANTs. The transformation matrices generated by these two steps will be concatenated, allowing images to be transformed directly from functional to MNI space in a single interpolation step.

We will define the amygdala region of interest using each individual's amygdala segmentation from FreeSurfer version 6.0. For the reverse correlation analysis, we will extract each subject’s average amygdala time series and normalize them. At each time point in the movie, we will use a one-tailed t-test across subjects to test whether amygdala response magnitude is above baseline. Events will be defined as two or more consecutive significantly positive timepoints (TR = 2s). To match the events to the movie, we will assume a 4s hemodynamic lag. Events will be rank-ordered according to the average amygdala response magnitude across subjects.

outliers.value:
Participants will be excluded if they:
- Have a neurological disorder, psychiatric disorder, or learning disability
- Exceed our motion criteria (>1mm average motion during the Piper movie, or if >30% of the time points are outliers as defined by ART)
- Did not watch the full Piper movie (i.e., because the child fell asleep, the movie was stopped early due to the child no longer wanting to participate, there were technical difficulties with showing the movie correctly, etc.)
- Have significant artifacts or problems with functional or structural image quality

dependent.value: The dependent variable will be the BOLD time course of the amygdala.

conditions.value: Participants are not assigned to conditions.

hypothesis.value:
Recently, naturalistic viewing paradigms have been used to probe neural representations in young children (Richardson et al., 2018; 2019). Here, we are interested in expanding upon this method by asking how young children ages 6 to 11 neurally represent emotional events in a 5-minute movie, “Piper” by Pixar. We hypothesize that amygdala activity will increase during the emotional (e.g., fear-related, surprise-related) events in the movie. 

We will test this prediction using the reverse correlation analysis approach from Richardson et al. (2018) with an amygdala seed, to see if this data-driven approach pulls out emotional events. Our goal is to test whether this approach bears out any signal with 1) a new movie and 2) with a new ROI.

In addition to the amygdala, we will also explore using the nucleus accumbens for reverse correlation analysis.
