q1.value: Beliefs and Experience of Dating App Use

q2.value: Margaret Tobias, Lindsay Labrecque, Mark A. Whisman

q3.value:
Research Questions:
1.	Do individuals’ thoughts and beliefs about Tinder differ according to their level of social anxiety?
To test this question, we will examine the degree to which social anxiety symptoms and severity of specific core fears in social anxiety are associated with individuals’ motivations for Tinder use and their affective attitudes toward Tinder.
2.	Does Tinder use differ based on social anxiety?
To test this question, we will examine the degree to which amount and frequency of Tinder use are associated with social anxiety symptoms and fears.
3.	 Do more socially anxious people experience different outcomes from Tinder?
To test this question, we will examine the degree to which frequency of certain Tinder use outcomes (e.g., text messaging, going on a date, having a sexual encounter, etc.) are associated with social anxiety severity.

q4.value:
Hypothesis 1a: Social anxiety will be positively associated with “ease of communication” and “self worth validation” motivations for using Tinder.

Hypothesis 1b: Social anxiety will be positively associated with negative affective attitudes toward using Tinder.

Hypothesis 1c: Social anxiety will be positively associated with positive affective attitudes toward using Tinder.

Hypothesis 2a: Social anxiety will be positively associated with frequency of Tinder use.

Hypothesis 2b: Social anxiety will be negatively associated with frequency of messaging a match.

Hypothesis 2c: Social anxiety will be negatively associated with frequency of responding to a match.

Hypothesis 2d: Overall, Tinder users will be less socially anxious than Tinder non-users.

Hypothesis 3a: Social anxiety will be negatively associated with frequency of in-person outcomes of all types.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: The present investigation is an observational study consisting of an in-person administered computerized survey. The study design includes both within-subjects and between-subjects features. Specifically, we have some sets of research questions and hypotheses that are suited to looking at individual differences within the group of Tinder users or the overall sample. Other sets of research questions and hypotheses concern group differences between Tinder users and non-users.

q9.value: The only form of randomization used in the present study is the randomized ordering of measures within the survey, which was achieved through the use of survey flow logic in Qualtrics. All participants began with the consent followed by demographics. Ordering of all other measures was randomized.

q10.value: Registration prior to any human observation of the data

q11.value: Data collection is complete. Data have only been downloaded from Qualtrics for the purpose of 1) creating a backup of the online-hosted file and 2) checking the balance in cell sizes for gender x user vs. non-user groups (per our a priori recruitment plan). Data have not been analyzed or examined in any way beyond calculating these cell sizes based on these variables.

question.value: N/A (Although these sections had been drafted prior to conducting data collection, they have been excluded from the preregistration, given that it was not submitted until after data collection was completed; see "Explanation of existing data.")

q13.value:
Note: data collection is complete for the study (see "Explanation of existing data").
Our target sample size was at least 200 each of Tinder-users and non-users. We aimed to recruit at least 250 participants from each group, assuming that insufficient effort responding, missing data, and technical difficulties would reduce our effective sample size for use in analyses.

q14.value:
Note: data collection is complete for the study (see "Explanation of existing data").
We used G*Power to conduct power analyses. Our goal was to obtain .80 power to detect small-medium effects at the standard .05 alpha error probability in two-tailed tests for both the analyses within the Tinder-user group alone and those comparing the Tinder-user to Tinder non-user groups .

question.value: N/A

-	Demographics:
-	Sex assigned at birth
-	Self-identified gender
-	Age
-	Race/ethnicity
-	Sexual orientation
-	Relationship status
-	Subjective social status

-	Psychopathology & related measures:
-	Social anxiety symptoms (SIAS)
-	Social anxiety fears (NSPS subscales: 1) concerns about competence, 2) signs of anxiety, and 3) concerns about physical appearance)
-	Depression symptoms (CES-D)
-	Neuroticism (NEO subscale)

-	Tinder-related measures
-	Motivations for using Tinder (subscales: Love, Casual Sex, Ease of Communication, Self-Worth Validation, Thrill of Excitement, and Trendiness)
-	Frequency of Tinder use
-	Usage outcomes (frequency of different types of sexual/relational outcomes, messaging, and responding to a message)
-	Attitudes toward Tinder (positive and negative subscales)
N/A

Hypothesis 1a: Linear regressions examining whether social anxiety symptoms are associated with either ‘ease of communication’ or ‘self worth validation’ subscales of the Tinder motivations measure.

Hypothesis 1b: Linear regression examining whether social anxiety symptoms are associated with negative affective attitudes toward Tinder.

Hypothesis 1c: Linear regression examining whether social anxiety symptoms are associated with positive affective attitudes toward Tinder.

Hypothesis 2a: Ordinal regression examining whether social anxiety symptoms are associated with frequency of Tinder use.

Note: Because it is colloquially believed that there are gender discrepancies in messaging behavior and experience on Tinder*, we will run preliminary tests for gender differences in our measures of likelihood of messaging a match and responding to a message. If gender is a significant predictor in either case, we will include gender as a covariate for analyses of Hypotheses 2b-2c.
*See Follow-up analyses for additional note about analyses related to gender.

Hypothesis 2b: Ordinal regression examining whether social anxiety symptoms are associated with frequency of messaging matches.

Hypothesis 2c: Ordinal regression examining whether social anxiety symptoms are associated with likelihood of responding to messages.

Hypothesis 2d: Independent samples t-test examining whether severity of social anxiety symptoms differs between Tinder users and non-users.

Hypothesis 3a: Linear regression examining whether social anxiety symptoms are associated with number of in-person meetups with individuals met through Tinder.

q20.value:
Transformation:
All variables will be checked for normality. Where skewness is encountered, we will make attempts to normalize the data through standard types of transformations, which include square root and log transformations. We will utilize the transformation method which most closely approximates a normal distribution.
	
Recoding:
Tinder use (yes/no) will be contrast coded such that betas can be interpreted as the group difference between users & non-users:

User = 0.5 ; Non-User = -0.5


Gender was assessed via two questions (1: sex assigned at birth; and 2: self-identified gender). Ongoing monitoring of gender X Tinder use cell sizes throughout data collection (see Explanation of existing data) revealed only four transgender participants (<1%) in the entire sample, leaving it insufficiently powered to detect differences between transgender and cisgender participants. We therefore use self-identified gender for planned analyses examining gender as a potential moderator (see Statistical models and Follow-up analyses), which will be contrast coded such that betas can be interpreted as the group difference between males & females:

Male = -0.5 ; Female = 0.5

Centering:
All continuous independent variables will be centered around the sample mean. Centering will also take place after any transformations described above.

q21.value:
We will make inferences based on p values using a criterion of p < .05 to define statistical significance. We plan to describe results where the p value falls between .05 and .1 as non-significant trends. We will use two tailed tests for our analyses.

We plan to address the multiple hypotheses tested in this project in-text (e.g., discussing the role for future confirmatory analyses).

q22.value:
Insufficient effort responding:
-	We will visually inspect free response items to look for responses that appear unrelated to question content, or which are blatantly in bad faith (e.g., “i’m bored”). Participants with such responses will be excluded from all analyses.
-	We will check the data for insufficient effort responding using two metrics: 1) response time, and 2) even-odd consistency (per Meade & Craig, 2012).
-	Response time: Participants whose response time for the survey was less than two seconds per presented item + 30 seconds (for consent) will be removed from the dataset.
-	Past research has suggested that 10-12% of undergraduate samples tend to be categorized as careless responders (Kurtz & Parish, 2001; Meade & Craig, 2012). If more than 15% of our sample is identified as insufficient effort/careless responders by the above methods (visual inspection and response time), we will examine the dataset further to assess the likelihood of false positives. Rationale will be provided for possible resulting revisions (e.g., use of an additional metric such as even-odd consistency) to the above criteria.

q23.value:
Incomplete data:
Participants will be excluded from analyses concerning a measure for which they have incomplete data.

q24.value:
In the present study, we are interested in the potential for specific core fears in social anxiety to uniquely predict individuals’ thoughts, beliefs, experience, and outcomes related to Tinder use. However, any specific predictions would be particularly speculative given the combination of the degree of novelty and specificity. Instead we will lay out the analytic plan for these exploratory tests:

For tests in which social anxiety is a significant predictor of an outcome variable of interest, we will follow-up analyses testing whether specific core fears (operationalized as the NSPS subscale scores) are associated with that outcome variable. To do so, we will run separate statistical tests examining the relationship between each subscale score and the outcome variable of interest.

Results will be presented as exploratory in nature, and subsequent limitations (e.g., the role for future confirmatory analyses) will be addressed in-text.
